title: 106_s382
content: The Act titled "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999" is established for the purpose of preserving historical sites related to the Minuteman Missile. The Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch facilities Delta 1 and Delta 9 are significant examples of Cold War history. They symbolize dedication and preparedness of Air Force missileers. These facilities offer a unique opportunity to showcase Cold War history, arms race, and ICBM development. The Act aims to preserve and interpret structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system. The Act aims to preserve and interpret structures associated with the Minuteman II missile defense system, highlighting its historical role in America's strategic commitment to world peace during the Cold War. It also complements interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established to preserve structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system, showcasing its historical significance during the Cold War. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota is established as part of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The site includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Control Facilities, with a map available for public inspection. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to make adjustments to the site's boundary. The Secretary is authorized to make minor adjustments to the boundary of the historic site and shall administer it in accordance with applicable laws. Coordination with other agencies such as the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State is required. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. Prohibited acquisitions include contaminated land. The Secretary can acquire land for the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. Prohibited acquisitions include contaminated land and land in South Dakota can only be acquired by donation or exchange. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years of funds being available for the Act. The Secretary can acquire land for the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. Land in South Dakota can only be acquired by donation or exchange. Within 3 years of funds being available, a general management plan must be prepared, including evaluating locations for visitor facilities and administrative sites. The plan should also consider coordinating with Badlands National Park for administrative and management purposes. The Secretary can acquire land for the historic site through various means. The boundary of the historic site may be modified to include a selected site. Coordination with Badlands National Park is considered for administrative and management functions. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Secretary to carry out the Act, including transferring Air Force funds for the maintenance of the historic site. The Legacy Resource Management Program funds for resource preservation and treaty compliance by the Air Force are not affected by this Act.
